newsitem.title: USA: Florida alleges toilet paper price conspiracy.
newsitem.headline: Florida alleges toilet paper price conspiracy.

text.p: Florida's attorney general filed a civil complaint Tuesday accusing 10 paper companies of fixing the prices they charged commercial and institutional buyers for toilet paper and other sanitary products.

The complaint was filed in U.S. District Court in Gainesville, Fla., against Kimberly-Clark Corp and its Scott Paper Co unit, Georgia-Pacific Corp, Fort Howard Corp, Bay West Paper Corp, Cascades Industries Inc, Encore Paper Co, James River Corp, Marcel Paper Mills Inc and Wisconsin Tissue Mills Inc.

The complaint alleges that the companies violated antitrust laws by fixing the prices of sanitary paper products sold to schools, hospitals, prisons, hotels, restaurants, factories and other large-scale purchasers.

Attorney General Bob Butterworth said the complaint seeks triple damages from each company, plus penalties of $1 million per violation of Florida's antitrust statute and $10,000 for each violation of the state's Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act.
"Beginning in 1993, these companies increased the wholesale prices of their commercial sanitary paper products dramatically," Butterworth said.

"Those price increases were made in virtual lockstep, indicating that the companies were working together to ensure higher prices to commercial consumers and larger, illegal profits for themselves," he said.
Butterworth said the price hikes could not be justified by economic conditions.

"In fact, the price of wood pulp, the major component in poaper manufacturing, had declined 18 percent since 1989, while the wholesale price of commercial sanitary paper had increased by 41 percent," he said.

Five of the companies -- Fort Howard, Georgia-Pacific, James River, Kimberly-Clark and Wisconsin Tissue -- together account for more than 80 percent of the national market for sanitary paper products, Butterworth said.
The five sell a combined $9 billion of products annually, one-third of which is bought by commercial users.
